Migration Guide

Migrating from other static site generators to unify is straightforward thanks to unify's emphasis on standard HTML and CSS. This guide provides practical examples for migrating from popular SSGs to unify's DOM Cascade system.

üîÑ Migration Philosophy

unify prioritizes standard HTML over proprietary templating languages, making migrations simpler and more predictable. Most templates can be converted by replacing template syntax with DOM Cascade area targeting.

Migration Overview

The general migration process involves three main steps:

  1. Convert layouts: Transform template layouts to unify layouts with public areas
  2. Update content: Replace template syntax with DOM Cascade area targeting
  3. Migrate configuration: Convert build settings to unify.config.yaml

Jekyll ‚Üí unify

Jekyll uses Liquid templates and YAML frontmatter. Here's how to convert common patterns:

Layout Conversion

Jekyll Layout
<!-- _layouts/default.html -->
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
  <title>{{ page.title }} | {{ site.title }}</title>
  <meta name="description" content="{{ page.description }}">
</head>
<body>
  {% include header.html %}
  
  <main>
    {{ content }}
  </main>
  
  {% include footer.html %}
</body>
</html>
unify Layout
<!-- _includes/_layout.html -->
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
  <style data-unify-docs="v1">
    /* Public areas */
    .unify-header { /* Site header */ }
    .unify-content { /* Main content */ }
    .unify-footer { /* Site footer */ }
  </style>
  <title>My Site</title>
</head>
<body>
  <header class="unify-header">
    <!-- Default header -->
  </header>
  
  <main class="unify-content">
    <!-- Default content -->
  </main>
  
  <footer class="unify-footer">
    <!-- Default footer -->
  </footer>
</body>
</html>

Page Conversion

Jekyll Page
---
layout: default
title: About Us
description: Learn about our company
---

<h1>{{ page.title }}</h1>
<p>This is the about page content.</p>

{% for post in site.posts limit:3 %}
  <h2>{{ post.title }}</h2>
  <p>{{ post.excerpt }}</p>
{% endfor %}
unify Page
<head>
  <title>About Us | My Site</title>
  <meta name="description" content="Learn about our company">
</head>

<body data-unify="/_includes/_layout.html">
  <main class="unify-content">
    <h1>About Us</h1>
    <p>This is the about page content.</p>
    
    <!-- Recent posts would be handled via a fragment -->
    <div data-unify="/fragments/recent-posts.html"></div>
  </main>
</body>

Configuration Migration

Jekyll _config.yml
title: My Jekyll Site
description: A great Jekyll site
url: "https://example.com"
baseurl: "/blog"

markdown: kramdown
highlighter: rouge
permalink: /:categories/:year/:month/:day/:title/

plugins:
  - jekyll-feed
  - jekyll-sitemap

exclude:
  - Gemfile
  - README.md
unify.config.yaml
# Basic site configuration
source: .
output: _site
clean: true

# Build options
pretty-urls: true
minify: true
verbose: false

# Development server
port: 4000
host: localhost

# Asset handling automatically included
# No plugins needed - unify is batteries-included

Hugo ‚Üí unify

Hugo uses Go templates and directory-based organization. Here's how to migrate:

Template Conversion

Hugo Layout
<!-- layouts/_default/baseof.html -->
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
  <title>{{ .Title }} | {{ .Site.Title }}</title>
  {{ block "head" . }}{{ end }}
</head>
<body>
  {{ partial "header.html" . }}
  
  <main>
    {{ block "main" . }}{{ end }}
  </main>
  
  {{ block "sidebar" . }}
    {{ partial "sidebar.html" . }}
  {{ end }}
  
  {{ partial "footer.html" . }}
</body>
</html>
unify Layout
<!-- _includes/_layout.html -->
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
  <style data-unify-docs="v1">
    /* Public areas - blocks become areas */
    .unify-header { /* Site header */ }
    .unify-content { /* Main content (block "main") */ }
    .unify-sidebar { /* Sidebar (block "sidebar") */ }
    .unify-footer { /* Site footer */ }
  </style>
  <title>My Site</title>
</head>
<body>
  <header class="unify-header">
    <!-- Header content -->
  </header>
  
  <main class="unify-content">
    <!-- Default main content -->
  </main>
  
  <aside class="unify-sidebar">
    <!-- Default sidebar -->
  </aside>
  
  <footer class="unify-footer">
    <!-- Footer content -->
  </footer>
</body>
</html>

draft: false
tags: ["web", "hugo"]
categories: ["blog"]
---

# {{ .Title }}

This is a Hugo post with **markdown** content.

{{< shortcode param="value" >}}

{{ .Content }}

title: "My unify Post"
date: "2024-01-15"
tags: ["web", "unify"]
categories: ["blog"]
layout: "post"
---

# My unify Post

This is a unify post with **markdown** content.

<!-- Components replace shortcodes -->
<div data-unify="/components/custom-widget.html"></div>

Gatsby ‚Üí unify

Gatsby uses React components and GraphQL. Migration involves converting JSX to HTML:

Component to Layout

Gatsby Layout
// src/components/layout.js
import React from "react"
import { useStaticQuery, graphql } from "gatsby"
import Header from "./header"
import Footer from "./footer"

const Layout = ({ children }) => {
  const data = useStaticQuery(graphql`
    query SiteTitleQuery {
      site {
        siteMetadata {
          title
        }
      }
    }
  `)

  return (
    <>
      <Header siteTitle={data.site.siteMetadata?.title || `Title`} />
      <main>{children}</main>
      <Footer />
    </>
  )
}

export default Layout
unify Layout
<!-- _includes/_layout.html -->
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
  <style data-unify-docs="v1">
    /* Public areas replace props */
    .unify-header { /* Header component area */ }
    .unify-content { /* children prop becomes content area */ }
    .unify-footer { /* Footer component area */ }
  </style>
  <title>My Site</title>
</head>
<body>
  <header class="unify-header">
    <h1>Default Site Title</h1>
  </header>
  
  <main class="unify-content">
    <!-- children content goes here -->
  </main>
  
  <footer class="unify-footer">
    <p>Default footer content</p>
  </footer>
</body>
</html>

Page Conversion

Gatsby Page
// src/pages/about.js
import React from "react"
import { Link } from "gatsby"
import Layout from "../components/layout"
import SEO from "../components/seo"

const AboutPage = () => (
  <Layout>
    <SEO title="About" description="About our company" />
    <h1>About Us</h1>
    <p>Welcome to our company!</p>
    <Link to="/">Go back to the homepage</Link>
  </Layout>
)

export default AboutPage
unify Page
<!-- about.html -->
<head>
  <title>About | My Site</title>
  <meta name="description" content="About our company">
</head>

<body data-unify="/_includes/_layout.html">
  <main class="unify-content">
    <h1>About Us</h1>
    <p>Welcome to our company!</p>
    <a href="/">Go back to the homepage</a>
  </main>
</body>

11ty ‚Üí unify

Eleventy supports multiple template languages. Here's how to migrate from Nunjucks:

Template Conversion

11ty Nunjucks
<!-- _includes/base.njk -->
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="{{ site.lang or 'en' }}">
<head>
  <title>{{ title }} | {{ site.name }}</title>
  <meta name="description" content="{{ description or site.description }}">
  {% block head %}{% endblock %}
</head>
<body>
  {% include "header.njk" %}
  
  <main>
    {% block content %}
      {{ content | safe }}
    {% endblock %}
  </main>
  
  {% block sidebar %}
    {% include "sidebar.njk" %}
  {% endblock %}
  
  {% include "footer.njk" %}
</body>
</html>
unify Layout
<!-- _includes/_layout.html -->
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <style data-unify-docs="v1">
    /* Blocks become public areas */
    .unify-header { /* Header include */ }
    .unify-content { /* Content block */ }  
    .unify-sidebar { /* Sidebar block */ }
    .unify-footer { /* Footer include */ }
  </style>
  <title>My Site</title>
</head>
<body>
  <header class="unify-header">
    <!-- Header content -->
  </header>
  
  <main class="unify-content">
    <!-- Default content -->
  </main>
  
  <aside class="unify-sidebar">
    <!-- Default sidebar -->
  </aside>
  
  <footer class="unify-footer">
    <!-- Footer content -->
  </footer>
</body>
</html>

Frontmatter and Content

11ty Markdown
---
layout: base.njk
title: "My 11ty Post"
description: "A blog post about 11ty"
date: 2024-01-15
tags: ["eleventy", "jamstack"]
---

# {{ title }}

This is content with {{ site.name }} variables.

{% for tag in tags %}
  <span class="tag">{{ tag }}</span>
{% endfor %}

{{ content | markdownify }}
unify Markdown
---
title: "My unify Post"
description: "A blog post about unify"  
date: "2024-01-15"
tags: ["unify", "static-sites"]
layout: "_layout"
---

# My unify Post

This is content with standard HTML.

<!-- Tags handled by a component -->
<div class="tags">
  <span class="tag">unify</span>
  <span class="tag">static-sites</span>
</div>

Standard markdown content continues here...

General Migration Tips

Template Language Mapping

Concept Other SSGs unify
Layouts Template inheritance DOM Cascade areas
Includes {% include %}, {{ partial }} data-unify attributes
Variables {{ variable }}, {{ .Param }} Standard HTML + frontmatter
Loops {% for %}, {{ range }} Components with data attributes
Conditionals {% if %}, {{ if }} CSS classes + JavaScript (client-side)

Common Patterns

Navigation Menus

Replace template loops with static HTML or JavaScript-generated menus:

html
<!-- Instead of template loops, use static HTML -->
<nav class="unify-navigation">
  <a href="/" class="nav-link">Home</a>
  <a href="/about" class="nav-link">About</a>
  <a href="/blog" class="nav-link">Blog</a>
  <a href="/contact" class="nav-link">Contact</a>
</nav>

<!-- Or use JavaScript for dynamic highlighting -->
<script>
  // Highlight current page
  const currentPath = window.location.pathname;
  document.querySelectorAll('.nav-link').forEach(link => {
    if (link.getAttribute('href') === currentPath) {
      link.classList.add('active');
    }
  });
</script>

Blog Post Lists

Create dedicated components for dynamic content:

html
<!-- _includes/post-list.html -->
<div class="post-list">
  <article class="post-item">
    <h2><a href="/blog/post-1">First Post</a></h2>
    <time>2024-01-15</time>
    <p>Post excerpt...</p>
  </article>
  <!-- Additional posts... -->
</div>

<!-- Use in pages -->
<div data-unify="/_includes/post-list.html"></div>

Migration Checklist

‚úÖ Migration Steps
  1. Identify layouts: Map template inheritance to DOM Cascade areas
  2. Convert includes: Replace template includes with data-unify fragments
  3. Update frontmatter: Simplify YAML frontmatter, remove template-specific fields
  4. Replace loops: Convert template loops to static HTML or JavaScript
  5. Handle conditionals: Move logic to CSS classes or client-side JavaScript
  6. Test build: Use unify build to verify output
  7. Update configuration: Migrate build settings to unify.config.yaml
  8. Deploy: Update deployment scripts for unify output

Migration Tools

Automated Helpers

bash
# Convert Jekyll includes to unify data-unify
find . -name "*.html" -exec sed -i 's/{%\s*include\s*\([^%]*\)%}/data-unify="\/_includes\/\1"/g' {} \;

# Remove common template tags (review changes first!)
find . -name "*.html" -exec sed -i 's/{{[^}]*}}//g' {} \;

# Convert layout frontmatter
find . -name "*.md" -exec sed -i 's/layout: \(.*\)/layout: "_\1.layout.html"/g' {} \;
‚ö†Ô∏è Review Automated Changes

Always review and test automated conversions. These scripts provide a starting point but may need manual refinement for complex templates.

üöÄ Migration Complete

Once migrated, you'll benefit from unify's simplicity: no template language to learn, predictable DOM Cascade behavior, and standard HTML/CSS that works everywhere.
